snippet: When children head to the New Hampshire polls with their parents, they bring questions along.
abstract: When children head to the New Hampshire polls with their parents, they bring questions along.
lead_paragraph: Because I live in New Hampshire, I got up bright and early this morning, loaded the kids in the car and headed out to vote. My children are 10, 7, 6 and 5, and the two oldest remember coming with me to vote in the last presidential election. But a primary is different, and more confusing. Even though I'd explained it several times in the last few weeks, only my oldest child, Sam, really remembered what the primary meant (and when I asked him to name some of the differences between the Republican and Democratic Parties, he offered that the Democrats were represented by a blue elephant - although he was able to correctly identify his grandfather as a Republican).

headline.main: Taking My Children to the New Hampshire Primary
